com.ibm.streams.beam.sdk.io

Class Topic

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ibm.streams.beam.sdk.io.Topic

  • public class Topic
extends Object
    Transformations that subscribe to streams published by IBM Streams or Beam applications, and publish to streams that can be subscribed by other IBM Streams or Beam applications. These transformations are specific to the IBM Streams runner.

    Publish-subscribe is a many-to-many relationship, multiple streams from multiple applications may be published on the same io and type. Multiple subscribers may subscribe to an io and type. A subscription will match all publishers using the same io and tuple type. Tuples on the published streams will appear on the returned stream, as a single stream. The subscription is dynamic. The returned stream will subscribe to a matching stream published by a newly submitted application (a job), and stops a subscription when a running job is cancelled.

    Publish-subscribe only works when the topology is submitted to a DISTRIBUTED context. This allows different applications (or even within the same application) to communicate using published streams.

    Publish

    Below is a minimum example to create a Topic.Publish transform that publishes long values.

    
 p.apply(Publish.ofType(Long.class).to(topic))

    The parameter of Topic.Publish.ofType(Class) will be the published data type and must match the input element type wrapped by the WindowedValue. It will also be the published data type. The Topic.Publish transform will discard all timestamp and watermark information on the input stream. If the application needs to preserve the timestamp, it could apply a ParDo transform before the Topic.Publish transform to enclose the timestamp data into the published data type. The two parameters of Topic.Publish are:

    • to(String) specifies the topic to publish to.
    • ofType(Class<T>) or ofType(TypeDescriptor<T>) specifies the published data type. The latter supports nested generic types, such as TypeDescriptor<KV<Long, Long>>. The published data class must be serializable. The application cannot pass a Beam Coder to Topic.Publish because there could be non-Beam subscribers.

    Subscribe

    Below is an minimum example to subscribe from a long topic: 

    
 p.apply(Subscribe.ofType(Long.class)
                  .from(topic));

    Topic.Subscribe transform imports a stream into a Beam pipeline. From Beam's perspective, it is the same as a Source transform, so applications are allowed to control timestamps and watermarks. The Topic.Subscribe transform takes two required parameters and three optional parameters:

    • (Required) from(String) specifies the topic to subscribe from.
    • (Required) ofType(Class<T>) or ofType(TypeDescriptor<T>) specifies the subscribed data type. The latter supports nested generic types, such as TypeDescriptor<KV<Long, Long>>. The subscribed data class must be serializable.
    • (Optional) withTimestampFn(SerializedFunction<T, Instant>) provides a function to extract timestamps from the subscribed data stream. If absent, timestamps of all tuples will be set to BoundedWindow.TIMESTAMP_MIN_VALUE.
    • (Optional) withWatermarkFn(SerializedFunction<T, Instant>) provides a function to create watermarks from the subscribed data stream. If absent, Topic.Subscribe will use the same SerializableFunction as Topic.Subscribe.withTimestampFn(SerializableFunction).
    • (Optional) setCoder(Coder<T>) provides the element coder. If absent, the transform will try to infer the coder from Beam's coder registry.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Topic.Publish<T>
      Applications can use the Topic.Publish transform to publish a Beam PCollection under a given topic, such that other Beam pipelines and Streams topologies may subscribe from it.
      static class  Topic.Subscribe<T>
      The Subscribe transform reads from streams published by other IBM Streams or Beam applications.
